ENGLISH is my third language and at times I lack the accuracy of expression that I would really like . When I sometimes try to translate my thoughts that are in Kiswahili and try to express them in English , inaccuracies occur and I beg your patience , dear reader .

By civilisation in my thoughts today I simply mean ' ustaarabu ' or being cultured . But if you look up the synonyms of civilisation , you find also , empire ( as in ancient civilisation ) , people , nation , progress , society , evolution , etc .

If I may borrow a simple scenario to express my ideas , a ' raw ' person from a small village , deep in the ' interior ' with little or no education may be termed a ' mshamba ' in simple town language .

He has no ' exposure ' and knows very little of the ' modern ' life . If he or she comes to live in the city for some time , he or @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ different people and gets ' cultured ' or in a certain perspective , this person gets ' civilised ' . I will use cultured and civilised interchangeably because of my Kiswahili background , even though this is not perfectly accurate .

Generally speaking , especially for the youth , their colleagues from the ' bush ' are not ' civilised ' . ' Washamba ' . They have many shortfalls ; they can not speak ' swanglish ' or in slang and they speak Kiswahili with a heavy accent of the vernacular ; they have no idea of the goings on in the world of pop or film . They've never been to a concert .

They can not drive , they do not know what a microwave oven is ... and they can not even operate the TV remote . Again , generally speaking , the Coast is where the ' culture ' meaning ' ustaarabu ' is . ' Ust-Arab ' ; it came by sea and landed on the coast .

The upcountry is ' culturally ' way back . I know ... there @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ but bear with me some more . People on the coast are more exposed because of other cultural influences . With widespread internet , this might change because the main issue is exposure .

Our grandfathers who went to the Coast in those days were known to be smarter men because they had had greater exposure to the world ! Advanced cultures usually are more developed in all aspects of life including science and technology .

Their lives are thus more comfortable by virtue of exploiting the benefits of scientific knowledge . We can have hot water in our taps without recourse to a trip to the well or river ; we can cook using the microwave or gas without having to go out for firewood . We can air condition our rooms to adjust temperature and consequently body comfort .

We can travel in luxury and communicate with friends and relatives hundreds and may be thousands of kilometres away ... Superficially there appears to be an association between a comfortable life and an advanced civilisation or an advanced culture . But based on the goings on in @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Our kids who leave the village and come to the city ; do they really get cultured or do they just enjoy the technological benefits of a ' relatively advanced culture or civilization ' ? Do they become better people ? More compassionate ?

More honest ? Let's go to the global framework . We might like to link power to ' civilisation ' . Is the war in Syria being conducted by civilised or cultured people ? Are they not flying powerful and sophisticated warplanes ?

Are the barrel bombs not technological marvels in their own way ? But is the user against a fellow human being civilized ? Is he cultured ? Imagine a society where one sleeps in a concrete , stainless steel and glass dwelling but needs multiple locks and security cameras and alarms before going to bed . Is that society cultured and civilized or just technologically advanced ?

In a society where man lives in a mud and grass hut but sleeps with the door open ( admittedly there is nothing to steal ! ) or on the veranda ; could @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ society since security ( a very basic need ) for its citizens is more assured ? Is killing others using a precision laser sighted weapon better than doing it with spears and knives ? With these questions can we start separating , culture , civilisation , power and comfort ?

If the war in Syria is a reflection of the civilization or level of culture of the current man , then we are indeed in a sorry state . This is indeed the Kal-Yuga , the Iron Age , a low point in human evolution .

The human race can be much better than this . As one intelligent man said , he could not reconcile in his mind a planet where hunger and obesity coexisted ! We can always say there is a problem in hand ; like the refugee crisis , but behind it all somewhere , there was an evil motive that started it all . What we see are the end results .

In many religious beliefs , there is the continuous war between good and evil ; they say good will always triumph @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ it . However , by the look of things at the moment , the Devil is leading on points .

IN this week's summation of the book : A Monument to China-Africa Friendship , Our Staff Writer , JAFFAR MJASIRI revisits the impact of TAZARA Railway and how it helped spread the Swahili culture in East , Southern Africa .

When I was doing my research two years ago , it was interesting to discover that Ugandans and Kenyans were leading in research and book publishing . It was at the Library of Congress where l learned this .

Actually I was interested to find out in East Africa which country was sending books and Research papers to the Library of Congress often . The leading country was Uganda , followed by Kenya .

But it is a talking point , and someone could come up with statistics as I could be wrong . In this review of government of People's Republic of China's master piece and memoir of Tanzania Zambia Railways Authority ( TAZARA ) which is again A Monument to China-Africa Friendship , which is the firsthand account of the building of TAZARA , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the components that made the project historical and was a catalyst to the spread of Swahili culture in Africa .

Based on the information which was recently shared by the only first Chinese interpreter who could speak Swahili in the team , Mr Ma Wangen , he helps us to understand how Swahili was so important to the construction of TAZARA .

It was imperative for the Construction team to use Swahili because the locals who worked in the project could only speak Swahili . " I was not able to serve many sub-teams at the same time , so it was imperative for me to train some " quasi-interpreters , " said the Interpreter .

It reveals that it is not true that one has to be in an academic institution to learn or embark on academic research . When the interpreter was deployed in the construction team , he was able to compile two books . He narrates to us that recently when he took the books out he was a little bit surprised , as he now discovered that they were indeed very systematic @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ popular brochure . I marked the pronunciation with Chinese characters , so that a Chinese expert who knew no foreign language could pronounce quite right by reading the Chinese characters , " he said .

The second book he had compiled was a literature containing reading materials , mainly some phrases . The textbook had altogether 22 lessons , followed by several songs , including the Swahili versions of China's revolutionary songs and local songs of Tanzania .

It was indeed an entertaining way of training young Chinese who joined the construction team and motivating them to learn . The interpreter said that each sub-team had recruited young people with some educational background and brought them to the general team .

The interpreter who had compiled the books was incharge of training them . One thing that we learn from this discussion on the importance of Swahili language is the desire by the Chinese experts to learn the African culture .

They did not want just to impose their value to the Africans but let us see those values through our own culture which in the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Swahili .

The evidence is the Chinese songs were translated , including " The East is Red " , " We are Determined " , and " We Need a Helmsman in the Ocean " , all with the political rhetoric at that time . According to the interpreter many local people were able to sing them and they sang them very well . It was like a Swahili course for beginners . The training was held for over a month .

Following the training , these " quasi-interpreters " became the backbones of each sub-team in the construction project . In other words they were instrumental in facilitating communication during the construction work . In the interpreter's words , which he says : " To be honest , some of them were no worse than Swahili majors ? This impressed me very much .

In such circumstances , bad communication would cause a lot of troubles . " Another capacity building exercise took place in which Tanzanian drivers were training to operate the scraper equipment .

The interpreter tells us that the Machine Repair Subteam @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and a theory class . " In the evening , people had theory courses , while they practiced in the day time and I served as an interpreter , " he adds . But he admits that he did not know some of the professional language , so he often turned to dictionary or used English to communicate .

It is important to appreciate what President Nyerere did for this nation . If you look at how Swahili has stood the test of time and became the lingua franca of East and Central Africa if not the world soon , it is worth to credit the three African leaders who opened the doors for the Chinese people to join the liberation struggle .

It was not only liberating the African countries from the shackles of colonialism and apartheid but even liberating the Swahili language to reach the world . The Chinese have their share in this language success .

How many of us are aware that Swahili in the 70s was still a language spoken by a minority group ? Its vocabulary was not large . But Tanzanians @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ developing this lingua franca in Africa .

It was through the railway line that people crisscrossed the region because it was made possible by TAZARA railway . It was that time when people were able to travel faster which helped to promote the Swahili language and culture . But even of significance was the Chinese method of teaching offered an alternative model from that of the colonialists to our people .

The interpreter argues that : " The colonialists only taught them how to drive , but we taught them bit by bit , from the engine's principle , the entire structure of the train , to the working principle of clutch and brake . "

It was only the Chinese who taught the Uhuru railway local workers principles , so that they could be independent and repair the equipment and machines themselves when there were small problems , which we can define as technology transfer .

The interpreter said that after a couple of months of intense training , there were 40 qualified local drivers in the sense of driver cum mechanics . What we @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ learning curve while carrying out the Uhuru liberation construction work can be a model for our trainers in the country .

Of course we missed that opportunity during that period of construction to at least be copy cats on the research and development of Swahili language . But it is not too late to borrow a leaf from their practices which enable them to accomplish a major liberation railway line that was a paradigm shift to the apartheid rule in Africa . Perhaps it is time for our academicians to expedite the process of writing Swahili books and avail them to many libraries around the world .

But it would have not been possible to achieve this magnificent railway line if there was no political will in the region . The presidents of Tanzania , Zambia and Chairman Mao of the People's Republic of China were indeed committed to seeing that this project was a success . Since we all know that the railway line enabled the freedom fighters to move in the region and enhanced the military logistics for the fighters .

In 1972 , the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and support . The interpreter remembers that the group was led by Guo Lu , Vice Minister of Transport . He had a gift for public speaking . There was also Ambassador Zhong Xidong , who spoke like a General . Their charisma was always met by the political will of the African friends ' emotional cheers and jubilations .

Some other leaders such as Chen Muhua and Fang Yi says the interpreter also came to inspect their work . But one of the testimonies given by the interpreter in terms of the three leaders who were behind the TAZARA success story , is the political will that was manifested in the person of the late father of the nation Mwalimu Nyerere , the late Vice President Rashidi Kawawa , Minister Lucenti , as well as various local officials such as governors who all attached great importance to the construction of the TAZARA . They usually visited the sites to inspect the project and send their warm greeting to both Chinese and local workers .

The district court at Ilala found Sumila guilty beyond reasonable doubt and threw him into jail . While we do not take delight in the father's predicament , it is highly critical to point out here that the punishment meted out on him is appropriate and should serve as a deterrence for cruel parents , guardians and other adults who often abuse children .

Sumila punched and caned his son because he was not attending school as he should , a situation that spurred one of his teachers to write to the parent a warning note . It is this warning that prompted the parent to fail to control his emotions . He attacked his son ruthlessly .

It is imperative to mention at the outset that child abuse is a nefarious atrocity . It is a crime that is punishable by law . When parents or other adults injure a child or do nothing to prevent it , this amounts to child abuse .

This includes hitting , shaking , biting and kicking . It also includes giving babies @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to sleep ! Yes , some parents abuse children this way . Sumila , the convict , drove a hard punch onto his son's mouth and caused irreparable harm . Some serious cases of child abuse can result in brain damage , hemorrhage and even death .

Caning is , arguably , the most common form of child abuse in this country . Incidents in which incensed parents bite their children are rare but they are prevalent . There are incidents in which parents burn their children's hands or feet after alleged thefts of small amounts of money , food or sugar .

This is stark raving mad , to say the least . Cruel parents often cause permanent disability in the children and ruin their lives . Some parents continuously fail to show love and affection to their children .

This is most evident when parents constantly use sarcasm , threats or criticism on children . Some yell at or taunt children . Emotional abuse can destroy a child's self-esteem , making him fearful . The effects of emotional abuse are serious and can @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ cause poor mental health and a lack of confidence in adult life . Some children flee their homes and try to make a living in the streets as beggars . In some cases , parents may come under intolerable pressure and stress , which prompts them to harm their own children .

Toddlers may be shaken or hit , or older children constantly put down and criticised in a manner that wrecks their emotional well-being .

Some adults may have been treated badly by their own parents and have not had the chance to develop better ways of raising children . Whatever the reason for stress - poverty or having been abused as a child - there is no excuse for abusing children .

Speaking during tree planting exercise at Kurasini Secondary School , the Tanzania International Container Terminal Services ( TICTS ) Corporate Development Director , Mr Donald Talawa , said the country needs more trees this time than any other in its history .

" Tanzania , like other developing countries , is facing one major environmental challenge : Massive felling of trees for firewood and charcoal . Therefore , we need to take serious measures to curb the situation before it is too late , " he noted .

Yesterday , TICTS staff joined teachers and students to plant trees . Mr Talawa said for Tanzania to achieve its middle income status target by 2025 , planting trees is essential for both economic and health aspect .

" With less or no trees , our survival is at stake ; but with more trees , we have nothing to lose but drought and hunger , " he said . He said TICTS , through this year's campaign ' Go Green Campaign ' , the company has decided to remind @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ as many trees as possible and teach our young ones the importance of doing the same .

He said : " We believe that if for every tree cut , three or more are planted , the threat of Tanzania becoming a desert in the future will be automatically averted and the best way to inculcate the culture of loving trees is by preaching it though action by planting as many as possible and teaching its benefits to children . "

The director went on to war : " If we allow deforestation to consume our country , we will eventually turn into beggars or perish of hunger .

We can't afford to go that path . " Mr Talawa said TICTS was in full support of the fifth phase government's initiatives aimed at easing economic hardships for citizens . However , he said ' wananchi ' also had a role to play since there were tasks to be undertaken by the government and those that fall on individual citizens .

SENSATION young forward Shiza Kichuya hit amazing late equaliser to earn 10-man Simba a hard-fought 1-1 draw against bitter rivals Young Africans in an ill-tempered Premier League game at the National Stadium in Dar es Salaam yesterday .

Defending champions Young Africans sought they had all but secured the derby bragging and three important points courtesy of Amissi Tambwe's controversial first half strike .

But with three minutes to go , Simba's wonder boy Kichuya scored direct from a corner kick to spark wild celebrations the Reds corner as the two giants settled for a share of spoils .

The former Mtibwa Sugar attacking midfielder , who has been a revelation at the Msimbazi Street since arriving at the start of the season , was incredibly accurate with his @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ swerve and dip on the ball , leaving Yanga custodian Ali Mustafa and his defenders helpless .

The result saw table-topping Simba move five points clear of second placed Stand United after reaching a 17-points tally from seven outings , whilst Yanga remained third with 11 points from six games .

This is the fixture that defines the season and after days of anxiety , the reality sunk in , unfortunately not without controversies . The Burundian striker appeared to control Mbuyi Twite's long pass into the box using his hand as he expertly beat defender Novat Lufunga before calmly slotting the ball past hapless Vincent Angban in the Simba goal .

The disputable apart , Tambwe demonstrated great deftness and predatory instincts , as he left Lufunga and his defensive partner Method Mwanjali in shadows . Referee Martin Saanya's decision to @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ fans , who ripped off chairs , throwing them onto the runway , Police had to use tear gas to disburse the culprits and calm the situation .

Hundreds of fans stormed out of the stadium , leaving behind some empty seats . Unfortunately , the incident occurred after Simba striker Ibrahim Ajib had initially been robbed off what looked a clear goal .

The stylish striker beat Mustafa with a stunning effort from outside the box only to be judged offside , with replays showing that he was almost a yard onside when he received the ball from Mkude .

Both teams showed to be overly cautious in the opening minutes and Yanga were the first to reach their opponents goal in the first minute but could not make the dreamiest of starts . In the sixth minute , Kichuya played in Ajib , who fired home on the turn but assistant referee flagged him off despite replays showing that he was well onside .

A minute later Tambwe unleashed a fierce shot narrowly wide from a corner kick . Kamusoko met Juma Abduls ' cross @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ target .

There was little to separate between the two sides until the controversial moment arrived after 26th minute . Twite spotted Tambwe just on the edge of the box with a high ball and the Burundian hitman , teased his marker , Lufunga with a clever body movement , but appeared to control the ball with his right hand before placing the ball past Angban . Nonetheless it didn't matter as the goal was given .

They say football unites people in a way politics never will and that proved to be the case after Home Affairs Minister Mwigulu Nchemba and the Chairman of the main opposition party , Chama Cha Demokrasia na Maendeleo ( CHADEMA ) , Freeman Mbowe , sitting together on the VIP section , celebrated Yanga's opener .

But Simba players and their supporters protested , forcing the game to be stopped for almost five minutes and the Reds eventually suffering double blows , after they were reduced to 10 players after the team's skipper , Mkude , was given the marching orders .

Police managed to restore order @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to get the better of Simba players but slowly they calmed down , found their feet and came storming back into the game on resumption having held off their opponents for the remainder of the opening half .

Despite numerical advantage Yanga failed to take an upper hand in the game and Simba deservedly drew the parity in the 87th minute thanks to that sensation goal by Kichuya , which denied Yanga a hat-trick of wins over their old foes . Yanga won both derby fixtures last season .

THE Arusha-based East African Court of Justice has dismissed a case filed by civil societies operating in Burundi , Tanzania , Uganda , Rwanda and Kenya against the government of Bujumbura , challenging last year's general election results .

The First Instance Division of the East African Court of Justice dismissed the case filed by the East African Civil Society Organisations ' Forum ( EASCOF ) against the Attorney General of the Republic of Burundi , the Independent National Electoral Commission of Burundi ( CENI ) and the Secretary General of the East African Community ( EAC ) .

EASCOF had alleged that the decision of the Constitutional Court of Burundi violated the letter and spirit of the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi of 2000 .

The Arusha Accord , which was promulgated into domestic law by the Parliament of Burundi , in particular Article 7(3) of Protocol 11 to the Arusha Accord , provides that the President of Burundi shall be elected for a term of five years , renewable only once and that no @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ EASCOF further alleged that the Constitution of Burundi states under Article 96 that the President of the Republic is elected by universal suffrage for a mandate of five years renewable once .

The applicant further alleges that by reason of the aforementioned breach of the Arusha Accord and the Constitution of Burundi , the decision of the Constitutional Court equally violated Articles 5(3) ( f ) , 6(d) , 7(2) , 8(1) ( a ) ( c ) and 8(5) of the Treaty for the Establishment of the EAC .

The forum further claimed that the decision of the ruling CNDD-FDD political party to nominate or put forward President Nkurunzinza as a candidate for election to the Office of the President of Burundi in 2015 violated the Arusha Accord aforementioned and was therefore unlawful . The Applicant also alleges that the CENI had failed to ensure compliance with the provisions of the EAC Treaty .

The court in its decision declined the application by the Applicant to review , revise the decision of the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Burundi . It further added that it has @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ does not extend to the interrogation of the decisions of other courts in a judicial manner such as being asked by the Applicant of the Constitutional Court in this matter .

EACJ said that the interrogation would require the Court to exercise the appellate Jurisdiction over the said decisions which jurisdiction the Court does not have .

The judges observed that the independence of the Courts of Partner States was a paramount principle of the rule of law as envisaged in Articles 6 ( d ) and 7 ( 2 ) of the Treaty , adding that they could not therefore in upholding those principles , interfere with that independence .

On the issue of the CNND-FDD to nominating Mr Pierre Nkurunziza as its presidential candidate for election , the Court decided that the issue was time barred .

That the decision was made on 25th April , 2015 and therefore any challenge to it pursuant to Article 30 ( 2 ) of the Treaty ought to have been filed before it on or before June 3 , 2015 . That since the Reference was filed on @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ matter was time barred .

The court further averred that it found no evidence that the Secretary General had breached any of his duties in the context of this Reference , adding that the powers and functions of the Secretary General were clearly spelt out in Articles ' 67 and 71 of the Treaty . The judges were therefore hesitant to hold the Secretary General accountable for any action on his part .

The court reiterated the matter was predicated upon a specific decision of the Constitutional Court of Burundi issued on May 25 , 2015 with attendant events . The court said that there was no plausible reason why the Secretary General was enjoined in this matter .

The court also observed that the second respondent , CENI , was struck out of the reference that it has never entered appearance , was also improperly enjoined in this matter .

They concluded that the Reference has brought to the fore the continuing and emerging questions regarding the rule of law in Partner States within the EAC . The Court , faithful to its mandate , has @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the Treaty and the same has to fail .

The court closed the matter and ordered each party to bear their own costs . The judgement was read by Justice Isaac Lenaola , Deputy Principal Judge First Instance Division .

" There is no any grain of doubt that the plaintiff ( Odama ) is entitled to be paid 30m/-by the defendant ( Director- Visa Newspaper ) being general damages for defamation , " he declared . The magistrate observed that there was evidence given by the plaintiff that as an actress in various movies , she was maliciously defamed by the defendant through its tabloid to lower her reputation in the society .

It was stated that the tabloid published an article on May 14 , 2014 , with a heading , " Odama Agawa Penzi kwa Kinyozi " literally meaning that Odama commits sexual intercourse with a barber .

" In a simple glance , the words of this nature where a publication is made to a person with an allegation of committing sexual intercourse by itself amounts to defamation to that person @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ matter , Magistrate Mwijage pointed out that the act of sexual intercourse was secret between the doers unless one of them decides to reveal the said secrecy .

According to him , that being a situation what the defendant published it was a clear defamation to the plaintiff . " It is very evident from the evidence of the plaintiff that she never committed any sexual intercourse with the alleged barber .

What the defendant did against the plaintiff was a mere and typical false statement , " the magistrate concluded . fter reading the article , it was stated that the plaintiff's friends visited her home place to give some sympathy . @@14637200 Here's all the crazy stuff that happened at the end of BYU's 55-53 win over Toledo Mack Brown left the broadcast , a wacky two-point conversion was scored and more

BYU beat Toledo 55-53 in the wee hours of Saturday morning . And yes , the game was every bit as insane as the score indicates . With eight lead changes -- all in the second half -- this was an ending worthy of honorary #Pac12AfterDark status even if neither team plays in the Pac-12 .

The last 15 minutes of the game were especially fascinating . Here's all that went down , in order ...

1 . Mack Brown left the broadcast mid-game : Yes , this really happened . In the fourth quarter , color commentator Mack Brown left the broadcast booth to catch a flight back to Bristol , Connecticut , to do studio work for ESPN . That left Adam Amin , the play-by-play man , to basically call the game by himself only with occasional help from the sideline . When you consider what transpired @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ fort . That's no easy task , and he handled it like a pro .

2 . Missed penalty on fourth down : Trailing 52-45 , Toledo quarterback Logan Woodside hit receiver Jon'Vea Johnson with a nice touch pass for an 18-yard gain on fourth-and-4 . A failure likely would have ended the game . Instead , it led to a go-ahead scoring drive . There's one caveat , though . Replay later showed that Johnson stepped out of bounds before making the grab , meaning he should have been flagged for illegal touching .

3 . A two-point try was converted after being fumbled : After a Kareem Hunt touchdown gave Toledo the opportunity to tie the game at 52 with an extra point , Toledo instead opted to go for two . Woodside was not prepared for the ensuing snap , but he still somehow managed to corral the fumbled ball and complete a pass to Michael Roberts for the conversion .

4 . Incorrect personal foul penalty called : Facing a first down on the Toledo 40 during its ensuing drive , BYU @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ grabbed running back Jamaal Williams . However , replay clearly showed that the Rockets player clearly grabbed Williams ' shoulder pad -- not his face mask . The ball was placed at the Toledo 17-yard line .

AP Biologists to measure impact of Yellowstone River fish kill

Tired of seeing surveys on articles ? Become a subscriber ! Log In or Subscribe

Rachel Leathe/Chronicle

In this Sept. 23 , 2016 photo , Rick Wollum , retail sales manager at Angler's West Fly Fishing Outfitters , rewrites the board outside the fly shop to reflect the open status of the Yellowstone River , in @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ inform anglers of which sections of the river were closed to fishing . ( Rachel Leathe/Bozeman Daily Chronicle via AP )

Rachel Leathe

This Sept. 23 , 2016 photo shows the Yellowstone River , from the Mallard's Rest Fishing Access Site , which is now fully open to recreation after a fish kill . ( Rachel Leathe/Bozeman Daily Chronicle via AP )

EMIGRANT , Mont . ( AP ) -- Rain fell on empty fishing access parking lots along the Yellowstone River on Friday morning . The river looked like chocolate milk -- fishing was going to be tough . Inside Angler's West , a fly shop here not far from the river , Rick Wollum answered a phone call .

" It's open , but it's dirty , " Wollum told the caller .

The murky water put a bit of a damper on what was an otherwise happy occasion for Wollum and other anglers and river users throughout the Paradise Valley , reported the Bozeman Daily Chronicle ( http : //bit.ly/2di20yv ) . It was the first day in the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the river they wanted . It was a long time coming , but few took advantage , leaving the river looking about as quiet as it was over the last month .

A little more than a month ago , Montana Fish , Wildlife and Parks shut down all water-based recreation on this river and its tributaries from the border with Yellowstone National Park downstream to the town of Laurel . It was a response to an outbreak of a parasite that biologists say killed tens of thousands of mountain whitefish .

The microscopic parasite causes proliferative kidney disease , and is believed to be new in the Yellowstone system . State biologists said low flows and high water temperatures likely made the parasite even more devastating for the Yellowstone's whitefish , and that the closure was necessary to prevent the spread of the parasite and to reduce stress on the fish .

But as late summer flirted with fall , river temperatures cooled and biologists stopped seeing so many fish dying . Section by section , the river was reopened . And now , people @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ will be allowed to return to normal . Businesses that took a hit when the river closed will lick their wounds and can begin trying to recover from their losses , and FWP biologists will begin planning how they will try to measure the overall impact .

" What I 'd like to see is FWP answer the question of to what extent is the population damaged , " said Pat Byorth , the director of Trout Unlimited's Montana Water Project .

Throughout the fish kill , FWP officials said they assumed they were only seeing about 10 percent of all the dead fish , if that . Agency staff saw more than 4,000 dead whitefish and a handful of trout , but they didn't see the ones that floated ahead of them , or that sunk to the bottom . FWP's regional fisheries manager Travis Horton has said he expects the impact to the population to be fairly significant , but it's going to be hard for them to answer how significant it is .

They won't be able to offer a @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to figure out what the population looks like . With trout , some of which were affected by the parasite , they will be able to compare population numbers from next spring to numbers gathered this past spring .

But with whitefish , that's going to be a lot tougher . Data on the species is far scarcer . They aren't exactly sure what the Yellowstone River's whitefish population looked like before the fish kill .

" Ideally we 'd like to have a quality estimate that we could go and look at , " Horton said . " But we don't have that . "

Old and weak

Mountain whitefish are native to Montana , but the species has always taken a backseat to the almighty trout . Anglers prefer big browns and rainbows to the snout-nosed whiteys . The hierarchy is evident even in the data Montana's state wildlife agency has collected over the years .

Trout per-mile estimates are done regularly on most major rivers in the state , but the same is not true of whitefish . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ as for trout . On the Yellowstone River , the most recent per-mile numbers for whitefish are 13 years old .

Biologists sampled whitefish on the Yellowstone in certain sections in 1999 , 2001 and 2003 , and the numbers are eye-popping . A few stretches of river in the Paradise Valley are listed as having more than 10,000 whitefish per mile .

Those numbers jive with what people have always thought ; that there are a lot of whitefish in the Yellowstone . Some think those numbers mean the fish kill is going to be a minor speed bump , that nobody will notice any impact to the population . Some think the real problem is that FWP stopped looking at the scaly salmonids .

" The real tragedy is that they quit counting them , " said John Bailey , the owner of Dan Bailey's Fly Shop in Livingston .

But Scott Opitz , FWP's Yellowstone River area biologist , said they stopped gathering the data because the estimates contained inherent biases that caused them to balloon .

" There was just @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ estimates when you couldn't really stand behind them , " Opitz said .

Per-mile estimates are arrived at through a method called mark and recapture . That means electrofishing crews float a river section two separate times . On the first run , they mark all the fish they catch so they can be recognized later . On the second run , usually a week or two later , the crews catch some of the same fish and some new ones .

The estimates hinge on the comparison of the two figures -- the new captures and the recaptures . But if the recapture rate is too low , the estimates are considered unreliable because it can inflate the final figure and leave a wide range of variability . The length of the river section they sample on can throw off the recapture rates , too . If it is too short , fish can move around and escape crews on their recapture run .

Low recapture rates and the length of the river section are two reasons FWP doesn't put much faith in the old @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Creek area in 1999 found there were 10,837 whitefish per mile there , but David Schmetterling , a research coordinator with FWP , said there were several problems with it . Samples were taken on just a half mile of stream , rather than the standard of a couple of miles . On the first run , crews caught and marked 299 whitefish . On the second run , they caught 511 , but only 20 of them were marked , which Schmetterling said was too low to be reliable . And the potential range for the estimate was between 8,027 and 19,368 , leaving a lot of room for variability .

Problems like that plagued most of the Yellowstone River whitefish estimates done between 1999 and 2003 , said Schmetterling .

" I think these are all over-estimates of population size , " Schmetterling said .

FWP realized that at the time , and so they stopped doing the estimates . Now , though , the old data will have renewed relevance as FWP tries to understand exactly what happened on the river this past August . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ a place to start , " Schmetterling said .

Though they don't consider the per-mile estimates to be solid , the raw data that makes them up will prove useful . The electrofishing runs reflect the number of fish they handled , and they can recreate those runs . Where a number falls in comparison will be somewhat telling , especially if it is significantly higher or lower .

" That's something we can easily do a followup with and have at least some level of comparison , " Opitz said .

Other options they are considering include trying to learn the distribution of fish of different sizes , which will give them a feel for whether any particular age class is missing from the population . They might also try out a genetic sampling technique that can tell them the number of breeding fish that contributed to the population . That method is still fairly new but might prove useful .

Connect with the Chronicle on Facebook for the latest news , links and more .

" It's going to take several @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ said . " Next year will be the first of many . "

Studying the canary

When fishery biologists talk about whitefish , they often call them the " canary in the coal mine . " Struggling whitefish populations are considered a sign of larger troubles in the river system , but for so long , the fish were so abundant they were considered a nuisance by many trout-obsessives . Byorth said biologists didn't think they needed to track their numbers .

" I don't think we can rely on that anymore , " he said .

Some work is being done . The species was recently studied on the Madison River , and Schmetterling said parts of western Montana are starting to pay more attention to the species .

Opitz himself regularly samples the whitefish population on a portion of the Shields River , but he said time constraints and river conditions have historically made the work tough on the Yellowstone .

" Areas where we can do that we are doing it , " Opitz said . " It's just @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and flow regime to squeeze that in . "

Now , though , the focus will likely be renewed . Catastrophe can make things like that happen , especially in wildlife biology .

" Oftentimes , biological interest is in the rearview mirror , trying to figure out what happened , " Horton said .

The parasite that caused this outbreak isn't going to disappear . In the Snake River system in eastern Idaho , the parasite is believed to be the culprit for five years of fish kills , all popping up around the same time of year . Each year the kill has lessened in intensity , which gives Montana's biologists some hope that the fish will build some immunity to it .

But there's no promise that will happen , and even if it does , fish will still be vulnerable to drought and high water temperatures , two other threats that aren't expected to go away .

Byorth said helping fish succeed might rely on creating river conditions that will help them weather the worst environmental conditions . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ or changing how people build near the river . The idea is to control human activity in a way that gives fish a fighting chance .

" If each fish has a chance to thrive , " Byorth said , " then the population thrives . " Watch this discussion.Stop watching this discussion . ( 0 ) comments Welcome to the discussion .

@@14637203 Court erases jury award of punitive damages against insurer

PHOENIX -- An Arizona court ruling erases a jury's award of $1 million of punitive damages to a motorcyclist who claimed that his insurer denied his claim in an accident case because the company short-changed policyholders to boost its profits .

The state Court of Appeals ruled that the motorcyclist wasn't entitled to punitive damages because trial evidence didn't show that American Standard Insurance Co. of Wisconsin reduced claims payouts to enhance its bottom line .

The ruling said American Standard treated Sobieski unfairly because it didn't consider evidence that would have contradicted a claims adjuster's finding that Sobieski was totally to blame for a collision that severely injured his leg .

@@14637204

A flurry of small earthquakes near the Salton Sea prompted researchers at the US Geological Survey to issue an earthquake advisory .

96 earthquakes above a magnitude 2 were observed between September 26-30 . Three of them were greater than 4.0 .

The USGS initially estimated up to a 1% chance ( 1 in 100 ) that a magnitude 7 or greater earthquake could be triggered along the Southern San Andreas Fault within 7 days . On September 30 , it was revised to a .2% chance ( 1 in 500 ) due to decreasing activity near the Salton Sea .

Gregg Wilkerson , a senior geologist with the Bureau of Land Management in Bakersfield says the seismic activity in the area was significant because " 75 percent of big earthquakes around the world have these swarms of smaller earthquakes before the big quake . "

Whether or not the flurry is a precursor to a larger event , Wilkinson says such clusters are rare and an advisory is not to be taken lightly .

" If you're in the business @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ too many warnings , otherwise its like the boy who cried wolf , " he said .

The advisory comes in the same week Gov . Jerry Brown signed a bill , giving $10 million to continue developing the state's early warning system .

While the early warning system can not predict earthquakes before they happen , they can give people short notice if one triggers nearby .

Depending on the distance from the epicenter , this can afford people precious seconds or sometimes minutes to find safety .

Senator Jerry Hill ( D-San Mateo ) says this could help fire stations " where the doors can come up before the shaking hits so we can make sure that they come up so the trucks and engines can get out . "

It could also give warning for trains to slow down , heavy machinery to stop or enough time to get under a desk .

California already has around 570 earthquake sensors . The new funding will nearly double that . Once the sensors are installed , however , the other big challenge @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to quickly disseminate the warning information .

" Most people assume that they'll get the earthquake early warning on their cell phone . And that's certainly a goal , " said Doug Given of the USGS . " But the system is currently not capable of delivering fast notifications to millions of people . "

He estimates the system will be fully operational within two years .

Kern County's western edge sits right along what's known as the " big bend " section of the San Andreas fault . Wilkerson says , the last big earthquake on that stretch was in 1857 . Statistically , he says the fault has a major quake every 120 years , which means it is continuing to build up pressure .

He suggests that everyone in Southern California be prepared at all times for a major quake . That not only includes having food , water and batteries , but knowing things like where to turn off the gas and where to meet if all communication channels are down .

@@14637207 After a dominant win over Stanford , college football fans were once again reminded that Chris Petersen is one of the sport's best coaches .

When the short list of " best college football coaches " gets thrown together every fall and spring , the same names always seem to end up at the top : Saban , Meyer , Harbaugh . If the author is feeling especially frisky , Dantonio or Patterson might be thrown into the mix as well .

Yet one name that has been conspicuously absent from the top of those lists the past couple years has been Chris Petersen , and that's a darn shame . After being under the radar for the past two and a half years at Washington , he proved again Friday night that there aren't too many coaches in college football better than him . If any at all .

On Friday , the Huskies didn't just beat No. 7 ranked Stanford , they dominated them in an emphatic 44-6 win at Husky Stadium . This game was a bloodbath @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @

The Huskies began the game going right at Stanford's weakness -- its defensive secondary -- picking at it like a scab waiting for the skin to break . And once Washington got an early lead , it poured it on . The Huskies dominated the line of scrimmage . They were more physical . They made fewer mental mistakes . Other than made-up stats like " angry jogs back to the sideline with their heads down , " Washington dominated every category there was to dominate .

Jennifer Buchanan

The Huskies were also the better prepared team , and it's thanks to Petersen . After following his career over a decade , however , this shouldn't have surprised any of us . Back in 2006 , Petersen took over an already great Boise State team and brought it to unprecedented levels of success for a non-Power 5 school during his eight years in Idaho . And while we all assumed he would do the same at Washington , I don't think any of us could have imagined it would happen this fast .

@ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ ago that Petersen took over a perennial seven-win club from Steve Sarkisian . The talent level was good , but not elite ( for example , Washington has signed zero five-star players since 2013 according to 24/7 Sports ; USC has signed 11 over the same stretch ) , and Petersen was forced to kick off a few of his best players because of attitude issues ( Marcus Peters ) . After Petersen lost a few more stars ( Shaq Thompson , Danny Shelton ) to the NFL Draft , it was assumed that it would take four or five years -- at best -- to get this program to the top of the Pac-12 . At worst , the Huskies would remain in seven-win purgatory for even longer .

Thankfully for U-Dub fans , that's just not how Chris Petersen rolls .

Jennifer Buchanan

The Huskies picked up steam late last year with three wins in their final three games ( by an average of 31 points ) and took that momentum right into 2016 , with five straight wins -- highlighted of course by Friday @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @'s way ; gone are guys like Peters , and in are a bunch of no-nonsense guys who stay out of trouble and focus on football . Myles Gaskin ( 18 carries , 100 yards rushing Friday ) and Dante Pettis ( four catches , 60 yards , one touchdown ) were both three-star guys who were overlooked by some of the bigger programs in the Pac-12 . At Washington they're what Petersen dubs " OKG's " a pseudonym for " Our Kinda Guys . " And the Huskies have a roster full of them right now .

With the win , the question now becomes " what's next " for the Huskies . Some think Washington is a national championship contender ( including my colleagues ) , and I don't disagree . Not only is Washington talented and hungry , but the schedule seems manageable in a watered-down Pac-12 .

Whether the Huskies get there , only time will tell . But when it comes to the question of whether Washington is " back , " the answer is an unequivocal " yes . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , the coach who is as good as anyone in college football .

@@14637213 Hueneme suffers first loss of season

Just moments after the final second ticked off the scoreboard Friday night , Hueneme coach Lui Toilolo had already put the score behind him .

Even though his team dropped its first game of the season , 40-15 , to Dos Pueblos , Toilolo had already found a positive perspective .

" What I take away from this was how hard we fought , " he said . " Gone are the days of the running clock . What I am most pleased about is years past we would have folded up our tents in the second half . Not this team . They just kept fighting . "

While the final score was decidedly for the Chargers , three crucial plays kept the Vikings from gaining momentum .

Two tipped passes and a goal-line stand as the clock expired at the half allowed the Chargers to build a 31-8 lead . Dos Pueblos wide receiver Michael Elbert pushed the lead to 14-0 when he scored on a 55-yard strike from quarterback Kellen Roberts . The @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and into the arms of Roberts .

Moments later a pass from Hueneme's Luis Pulido was deflected and intercepted by Dos Pueblos defensive back Josh Feldhuas . Roberts connected on the next play on an 11-yard touchdown pass to Cyrus Wallace for a 31-8 lead .

Hueneme tried to answer before the half and moved the ball quickly down the Chargers ' 1-yard line . Hueneme had two rushes from point-blank range , but was turned away and the clock expired on the half .

" If we score down there at the end of the half we come out in the second half with a different light , " Toilolo said . " Those plays made a big difference . "

Each of the plays kept the Chargers in control .

" Those were big plays , " said Dos Pueblos coach Nate Mendoza . " Thankfully , we made that goal-line stand and that did a lot for us going into the half . "

Mendoza was pleased with his team's effort on both sides of the ball .

" @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , " he said of Hueneme's 5-0 start to the season . " We needed our defense to hold them down and they did . "

Kelly Clarkson is one of the few contestants from American Idol to have forged a lengthy and successful career . Since winning the show 14 years ago in 2002 , Clarkson has gone on to record some of the biggest and best pop hits of all time , including the stomping ' Since U Been Gone ' .

At 34 , Clarkson has since signed a new record deal with Atlantic Records , and is set to release new music very soon . So , with that in mind , we've delved into the singer's back catalogue to unearth some of the surprising stories behind her biggest hits .

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

1 . ' Miss Independent ' was rejected TWICE before Kelly recorded it ...

While ' Miss Independent ' wasn't Kelly Clarkson's first single , it sort of feels like the moment where her career began . After winning American Idol , Clarkson released a double A-side , ' Before Your Love ' / ' A Moment Like This ' , but it would be @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , the boring reality TV show ballads were gone , and ' Miss Independent ' proved that Clarkson had attitude .

In fact , ' Miss Independent ' ( originally titled ' Miss Independence ' ) was meant initially for Destiny's Child . Not too bothered with the track , the band turned it down and it made its way into the hands of fellow vocal powerhouse , Christina Aguilera .

Aguilera , who was at the time putting together her album Stripped , heard the song and even re-wrote the song's lyrics with Rhett Lawrence and Matt Morris , who she was working with at the time .

Writing in his book , The Soundtrack of My Life , legendary record producer and label exec Clive Davis said that he came across the song while putting together Clarkson's debut , Thankful . " It had been intended for Stripped , " Davis explained , " though she never finished recording it . "

Continuing , he went on to reveal that the song was then offered to Clarkson by songwriter Rhett Lawrence without @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ you can imagine , Xtina was pissed . " I don't blame Kelly , the song is a good choice for her , " The Sun reported Aguilera as saying . " I blame the people who didn't let me know what they were doing . "

In his book , Davis tried to shake responsibility for the incident . " I was under the impression that Lawrence had cleared it with her , " he said . " Initially Christina was upset , but the situation sorted itself out . "

Obviously , most of this negotiating over songs occurs without the popstar's knowledge , and as Clarkson explained she had no idea what had been going on .

" Somebody gave me this song , and it was half done and I was , like , cool , " she told The Daily Telegraph . " The hook sort of had this Christina Aguilera spirit , but nobody ever told me . I think they were kind of nervous that I wouldn't want it because of that , but I think that @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , I don't care . "

Continuing , she added : " Christina is getting paid a lot of money for not even doing it , so I mean she's probably loving it . "

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Following this drama , however , things weren't 100% smooth sailing . After recording the track ( and retitling it ) , it was a battle to even get the song included on Clarkson's debut album . " I've had to fight on every record to get what I wanted on there , " the singer told the Bournemouth Echo . " I had to argue with the record label to the point of literally crying to get ' Miss Independent ' on the album , then they released it as my debut single and it was a hit . "

Like ' Miss Independent ' , ' Since U Been Gone ' began its life as a song for someone else . Initially , according to producers and songwriters Max Martin and Dr Luke , the track was offered to Pink @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Luke said didn't have the range to pull it off .

At the time , Max Martin was in a bit of a slump . The veteran pop producer hadn't had a massive pop hit for a few years , and he 'd even closed Cherion studios , the production house that had helped elevate Britney Spears and N*Sync to pop superstardom .

Shifting gear , Martin and his then-prot ? g ? Dr Luke decided to try something different . After listening to a lot of indie and rock music , the pair were frustrated that they lacked a proper " damn good pop chorus " .

" It was driving Martin nuts , " Dr Luke told Billboard . " That indie song was sort of on six , going to seven , going to eight , the chorus comes . . . and it goes back down to five . It drove him crazy . And when he said that , it was like , light bulb . ' Why don't we do that , but put a big chorus on it @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Hilary Duff both turned down the song , the track found its way to Clive Davis , who heard it and loved it . Despite this , Martin wasn't convinced that Clarkson was the right person for the track . " I don't think Max even knew who Kelly was , " Dr Luke told Blender .

" Max was looking to move on from what he had done with Backstreet Boys , " Davis told Billboard , " and I really spent time convincing them that an American Idol winner could bring all the feeling and passion that was required to the song . "

That wasn't the only issue though . Kelly Clarkson herself wasn't actually too keen on the track either . " It didn't have any lyrics and the melody really wasn't finalised , " she recalled , speaking to the Hollywood Reporter . " The track was done on a computer , there was no band on it . My record label was freaking out about it and I was , like , why ? "

Initially @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ oh dear ) . " I asked if we could rock the track a little , " Clarkson said , speaking about when she first heard the song . " We put some heavier guitars and harder drums on it . Now it's explosive . "

" Obviously it's not Metallica , " she later said to MTV , " it's still pop-rock , but it's so much fun for me . "

' Since U Been Gone ' has gone on to be widely recognised as one of the greatest pop songs of all time .

3 . ' Behind These Hazel Eyes ' is about a " dipstick " who broke Kelly's heart ...

Another collaboration with Max Martin and Dr Luke , ' Behind These Hazel Eyes ' was the second single lifted from Kelly's second album Breakaway .

Recorded around the same time as ' Since U Been Gone ' , the track was actually a peace offering from Martin and Dr Luke . " We had just done with ' Since U Been Gone , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to Billboard . " We sent a rough version of ' Behind These Hazel Eyes ' , without any lyrics , to Kelly and Clive Davis . It was in part an olive branch to Kelly , because there was miscommunication on ' Since U Been Gone ' where Kelly had written some lyrics and Max and I didn't know about it and we had finished the song . "

While the trio wanted to work on the song together , the fact that Clarkson was touring and Dr Luke and Martin were based in Sweden at the time meant that they had to share everything via email . While that's how most songs are recorded today , it wasn't quite how things were done back in 2004 .

Following a break-up with ex-Evanescence member David Hodges , Clarkson wrote the song's lyrics . " I had literally been alone for two years , then ended up meeting this guy , " Clarkson told Blender magazine . " Everybody does that -- you're alone , and then all of sudden you meet someone , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ you latch on to . It's not so much the person as that experience -- that life that you want . "

Continuing , she went on to say that the relationship ended " horribly " . " It's a shame . I'm friends with my two other ex-boyfriends , and it's a shame because we probably won't ever be able to be . "

More succinctly , she told Entertainment Weekly , that the song was about a " dipstick who completely screwed up and now is unhappy . "

After working collaboratively with Dr Luke on the lyrics , Clarkson said that the track was her " favourite song on the album " .

4 . Kelly really battled to get ' Because of You ' released ...

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

While Clarkson's music has generally been personal ( except a miss-communication during ' Since U Been Gone ' ) , ' Because of You ' was Kelly Clarkson laid bare .

A version of the song was written when Clarkson was just 16 @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ I tend to write on the darker side , " Clarkson admitted to Blender " I like songs when you can actually hear the person cry . It's free therapy . "

The song , which deals with strong emotions and the effect that your elders have on you , was , Clarkson says , initially met with criticism . " That song really is the most depressing one I've ever written , " she said to the Guardian , before going on to explain how the song was shot down at almost every opportunity .

" I tried to get it on Thankful , and was laughed at and told I wasn't a good writer , " she said in one interview . Likewise , following the release of Clive Davis ' revealing book , Soundtrack to My Life , Clarkson revealed how she " cried because Davis hated it and told me verbatim that I was a ' shitty ' writer who should be grateful for the gifts that he bestows upon me " .

Despite this , Clarkson fought to get the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ results , " she said about when the song was finally released , " people responding to it , and allowed it to become a single . Then took credit for its success , of course . "

Echoing these sentiments , she told Entertainment Weekly that there was blood , sweat and tears involved . " I think I'm most proud of that song , " she explained . " Just getting it on an album because no one liked it until it hit No.1 worldwide and everybody was on board . "

5 . ' My Life Would Suck Without You ' was originally a song about smoking illicit substances ...

Following a lacklustre third album that saw Clarkson head down a darker route , it seemed that topping the charts was back on the agenda when it came to her fourth collection , All I Ever Wanted .

Joining forces again with Max Martin and Dr Luke ( the Kelly Clarkson dream team ) , Clarkson explained how the track was probably her least favourite , but also her most favourite track of @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ I first heard it , it did not sound like what it sounds like now , and I really had to fight to make that song better than it was , " she told Same Same .

Expanding on this , Clarkson told how the song's lyrics were originally about smoking pot and trying to look cool . " I was like ... What ? I didn't even get it , it was trying so hard to be edgy and cool that I wanted to vomit ! I didn't really like it at all . "

However , after some tinkering , the track was given a new lease of life . " For Martin , Dr Luke and Claude Kelly , the song's writers to go away and tailor the song specifically for me was really cool . We made it a non-boy-bashing song , as opposed to the songs I usually do . "

Following its release , ' My Life Would Suck Without You ' broke Billboard's history , trumping Britney Spears for the biggest single week rise to number @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the American music chart .

While ' Stronger ' may sound like a Max Martin and Dr Luke concoction , the track isn't actually anything to do with the pair . Instead , fellow Swedish hitmaker J ? rgen Elofsson wrote the track with Ali Tamposi , David Gamson and Greg Kurstin .

Initially , ' Stronger ' was meant for Leona Lewis , who incidentally had sung the same song as Kelly Clarkson for her X Factor winner's single , ' A Moment Like This ' . Unfortunately , Lewis turned the track down while it was being written , leaving Clarkson free to swoop in and turn it into one of her finest moments of power pop .

Songwriter Ali Tamposi explained how the idea of the song came to her after she 'd had a really bad day . Rumours were flying that her boyfriend of the time was cheating on her , and Tamposi was hysterical .

While driving to the writing session , it took her mother , who was staying with her at the time , to calm @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ " What doesn't kill you makes you stronger , " the track was born .

It seems that Clarkson's A&R process isn't without its hitches , however . " We had no idea where the song was going to go or it if it was even going to get to Kelly , " Tamposi said . " Finally , her management approved the demo , then Jeff Aldrich approved it and they sent it to Kelly who immediately loved it . So from September when it was written it wasn't until about January 2011 that we got word back Kelly loved the song . "

Speaking to the Associated Press , Clarkson admitted that she was proud of the track . " I knew from the moment I heard it that it was going to be huge . I've heard everything from ' I got out of an abusive relationship ' to ' I'm surviving cancer ' ... and I think everyone in the world needs that type of song - something that makes you feel empowered . It's a perfect representation @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @

@ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ 2007 outbreak and we are really not sure why there has been a resurgence here all of the sudden , " she said .

@@14637221 Tiger Woods : Tracing the Ryder Cup Struggles of a Golfing Icon

Curtis Strange faced a question that has confronted every American golf captain since 1997 -- what do I do with Tiger Woods ?

The first time most people saw Tiger was in a Nike commercial . " Hello world , " he said in 1996 , a month after signing the first of several enormous endorsement deals . We listened as Woods talked over stirring images of himself as a child , through footage of him as a world-beating amateur . The myth-making iconography remained pretty much in place over the course of nearly two decades ; the component parts of Brand Tiger -- the fist pump , the smile and the impassive , unrelenting stare into the camera .

Woods captured the imagination in a way no golfer had since Arnold Palmer in the early days of television . The first Major win at Augusta in 1997 was not only brilliant , it was so ' on brand . ' The black kid winning at the Masters , where his skin @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ it was compulsory to have a black caddie until 1983 .

The Tiger of the Nike ads conflicted with the other public version of Tiger Woods , which could be found at press conferences and in media interviews -- an environment every bit as false as advertising . Tiger is famously hard to fathom at these moments when he is contractually obliged to talk the media . He is cool , aloof and can sometimes come across as irritated and arrogant . Despite this , the press gave him a remarkably easy ride , either too in awe of the brand or too scared of his handlers to delve too deep or ask difficult questions .

In this way , Tiger's relationship with the media pre-2008 was somewhat out of time , a throwback to the way Hollywood curated their stars ' images during its " golden era " of the 1930s , when famous people were untouchable , protected by the film studios ' publicity machines . Few of us peered too far behind the billboard fa ? ade that had been erected for our enjoyment . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , the real Tiger was there for all to see and , like most of us , it wasn't pretty . Unlike the flawless face on the poster , the real one had warts . In other words , he was human , and we hated him for it .

" The Captain Myth " by Richard Gillis . Bloomsbury

Both versions of Tiger -- the man and the brand -- have been a fascinating side story to the Ryder Cup since he made his debut at Valderrama in Tom Kite's team . He traveled to Spain as the holder of the Masters green jacket , but his form was frustratingly sketchy . This was put down to first night nerves , or tiredness , or trying too hard to be the boy wonder , as one caddie put it . The deeper analysis into Woods's erratic relationship with the event would come later .

Kite partnered Woods with his friend Mark O'Meara on the first morning of the match . Expectations were oddly low even then , this time due to the course , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ . " If you are going to pick a course in the whole world that would be a bad course for Tiger Woods , this is it , " said Johnny Miller . " It is the narrowest course and has the smallest greens I've ever seen . It's got trees overhanging the fairways . This is a precision course .

This is a Ben Hogan course ... it is not a Tiger Woods course . "

Despite Miller's concerns , Woods settled well enough . He hit a 2-iron from the tee of the 535-yard fourth followed by a 9-iron lay-up and a wedge to the green , holing the putt for a perfectly executed " Hogan-like " birdie . This gave the partnership a lead over Montgomerie and Langer they would never relinquish , running out 4 and 2 winners on the 16th .

The good start was misleading . The same four players went out against each other in the afternoon , with the European pair handing out a 5 and 3 win . Woods went from OK to worse the next @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , again partnered with O'Meara . In front of former President George Bush , Woods putted off the 18th green into water , finally going down 2 and 1 to Faldo and Westwood . Worse was to come for Tiger on Sunday , when he went down 4 and 2 to the unfancied Italian Costantino Rocca , leaving the American with a 1 -- 3 -- 1 record for his first three days in Team USA colours .

The up and down nature of that first outing has been repeated many times since . In a career that has had many high points , it's unlikely that he has ever played better than he did through 1999 and 2000 , either side of Brookline . Woods won eight times on the PGA Tour in 1999 , the first player to achieve this feat since Nicklaus in 1974 . A few weeks before the Ryder Cup , he had seen off the challenge of Sergio Garc ? a to take the USPGA Championship , the final Major of the year .

The season that followed was even better . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the longest winning streak since Byron Nelson in 1948 , and he became the youngest player ever to win all four Major championships , broke the scoring record for the lowest stroke average in tour history and won three of that year's Majors , including the U.S. Open , by ten shots . Not for the last time , however , Woods failed to bring this level of play to the Ryder Cup . Ben Crenshaw paired him with three different partners during the week -- Tom Lehman , David Duval and Steve Pate -- and got just half a point from a possible four in return over the first two days .

" You kind of scratch your head and say , ' What do I do to help this guy ? ' " wrote Crenshaw later .

The pattern was set , as subsequent captains tried and largely failed to find a formula that would bring the real Tiger Woods to light in American colors . Across Ryder and Presidents Cups , Woods has had 18 different playing partners since he teed off with O'Meara at @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ -- 2 in his singles matches across his 14 Ryder and Presidents Cups and 33 -- 31 -- 4 in matches at these competitions .

There is nothing like the feel of the kind of statement game Washington had against Stanford , winning 44-6 Friday night and into Saturday morning . You crush your conference's traditional powerhouse , and the statement is this :

Hello ! Washington is here again !

But there was a missing element to that statement . A great statement , like a great concert , speech or event requires someone to hear it , someone to see it , someone to believe it . Friday night and into Saturday morning ? What kind of a timeline is that ?

Being honest , the Pac-12 doesn't have a lot of marquee games now that USC has become irrelevant . But when it has one and puts it on over midnight to most of the nation's population , it comes off like a coyote howling in the night . It's sort of happening out there somewhere .

This season , we have already seen so many defining statement games , and they've all met the criteria for a national discussion @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ then pounded Michigan State . Houston beat Oklahoma . Even Texas arrived again with its win over Notre Dame .

Those games drove the sports world's discussion the next day . This one could be forgotten by noon .

But that's what the Pac-12 had with No. 7 Stanford-No. 10 Washington , too , and its game came off like an opening act . You put a game on at an odd time like that if you're the MAC , just figuring that if you're on against the big boys , no one will watch you . The other game Friday night was Toledo vs . BYU .

When the next ESPN show came on , one of the first things host Scott Van Pelt said was this : " I'm not tired yet ! "

In the end , maybe it won't hurt Washington's chances to be one of the four teams in the College Football Playoff . But you want to create a buzz , even if just for potential recruits .

What could Washington have done @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ game on its schedule . And it did that masterfully .

But are we really supposed to believe in these guys ? Here's my short answer :

Yes .

But here's a quick quiz : Name one player on Washington's team .

Give up ?

Washington is now the only team west of Texas that still has a shot at the national title . I mean , who would have thought that Washington would be the only representative alive from the left half of the country ?

Washington ? It was mediocre last year and brought a lot of people back . College football is all about player development , though , and that's apparently something coach Chris Petersen gets .

Fairly or not , West Coast football has the image of a wild , up-and-down game -- except for Stanford , which beats you with repetitive body blows until you just sort of sit down and give up .

Washington did not beat Stanford the way Oregon always tries to , by running away as fast as possible @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ also beat it up .

There is no way anyone from the Southeast is going to take Washington seriously . But I , as a Midwesterner , thought it was a thing of beauty .

" All we heard about all week leading up to this , if you were listening to media -- which you're not supposed to do -- but all we heard was Stanford's O-line and D-line , " Washington quarterback Jake Browning said . " We took that personally . "

Otto Greule Jr/Getty Images

Yes , Washington's lines looked as if they were twice the size of Stanford's . That's exactly where the game was won . There wasn't even anywhere for Stanford running back Christian McCaffrey to run . He got just 49 rushing yards and 30 receiving yards .

His Heisman chances are done . Stanford isn't going to make the playoffs .

But Washington did look like the type of power team that could transcend and work outside of the West Coast .

In January 2015 , Oregon and @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Rose Bowl . It was a statement game for the entire Pac-12 that it belonged . But now Oregon has dropped off , and USC has disappeared .

And it's going to take some work to believe in Washington . This year , we're having to adjust our perceptions of college football programs , though .

Last week , I called this season college football's Brexit , as establishment teams keep falling . So we're still adjusting to Louisville , Wisconsin , Houston .

@@14637223 Sedona Red Recap : D-backs open final series of season with win over Padres

Arizona Diamondbacks ' Chris Owings , right , smiles after hitting a two-run home run against the San Diego Padres during the sixth inning of a baseball game , Friday , Sept. 30 , 2016 , in Phoenix . ( AP Photo/Rick Scuteri )

It's been a trying season for the Arizona Diamondbacks , and with just a couple games left , the best they can do now is look to close it out with a strong series against the San Diego Padres .

So far , so good .

Paul Goldschmidt and Chris Owings homered , and the bullpen delivered another solid outing as Arizona ousted San Diego by a final of 5-3 in front of 42,651 fans at Chase Field on Friday night .

For Goldschmidt , it was his 24th longball of the season -- and it was a no-doubter . He took a 2-0 pitch from Padres starter Edwin Jackson and blasted it onto the balcony in center field , just above the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ 3-1 lead , but San Diego rallied to tie it in the fourth . Owings broke the deadlock in the sixth , though , when he lofted his fifth homer of the year into the right-field seats .

That proved to be all the offense Arizona would need , as the bullpen came through with four scoreless innings to close it out . With the victory , the D-backs have now won six of their last eight home games . Overall , they sit at 67-93 -- one game back of San Diego for fourth in the NL West .

THE GOOD

-Braden Shipley got out of a jam in the first to keep the game scoreless early on . With runners on second and third and only one out , he fanned Yangervis Solarte and got Alex Dickerson to fly out to center to end the inning .

-Goldschmidt's homer traveled 428 feet .

-In addition to his game-winning homerun , Owings made a nice defensive play on a sharp chopper in the ninth . He was also able to fire to third in @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Hunter Renfroe , who was looking to advance from second on the play .

-Patrick Corbin turned in another solid performance , tossing 2.2 shutout innings while striking out three . This was likely the last appearance of 2016 for the 27-year old lefty , who is definitely finishing the season on a high note .

THE BAD

-Shipley took a Manuel Margot liner off the arm in the first . He was able to stick around though , and even managed to get the ball to second for an out on the play .

-Shipley allowed the leadoff hitter to reach base in three of the first four innings . It only came back to bite him in the fourth though .

-Ryan Schimpf's fourth inning home run was his 20th of the season -- six of which have come against Arizona .

STAT OF THE GAME

3 : Number of errors made by the Diamondbacks in this one .

HE SAID IT

" We always tell our guys ' we want you to run through first base ' . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ . Run through the base , don't run to the base . So we want to finish the season that way -- run through the finish . " -- Chip Hale , on the importance of closing out the year with a strong series at home .

NOTED

-- Solarte was called out to end the third inning because he batted the ball while stepping on home plate .

-- Owings won the second annual Luis Gonzalez Award before the game .

-- Earlier today , Jean Segura was announced as one of the finalists for the NL Comeback Player of the Year award .

UP NEXT

The D-backs have just two games left in the 2016 season , both of which will be played at Chase Field against the Padres . Saturday's first pitch is set for 5:10 p.m. , with pregame beginning at 4:30 p.m. on Arizona Sports 98.7 FM . Archie Bradley will get the start for Arizona , while San Diego counters with Clayton Richard .

Bradley ( 7-9 ) will be wrapping up his rookie campaign , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ late . He's allowed three runs or less in five of his last seven starts , though he did run into trouble against Washington in his most recent outing on Sept. 26 . In that game , he was touched up for four runs in 3.2 innings , but did not factor into the decision .

Saturday will mark Bradley's fifth career start against the Padres . He's 1-1 with a 5.48 in his first four meetings .

Bradley also has 132 strikeouts on the year -- good for third most over by a D-backs rookie , behind Wade Miley ( 144 , in 2012 ) and Brandon Webb ( 172 , in 2003 ) .

Richard ( 3-3 ) began the year with the Cubs , where he made 25 appearances out of the bullpen . Since arriving in San Diego , he's made eight starts , and he's been successful for the most part , notching three wins and a 2.01 ERA .

In two starts against Arizona this year , Richard is 1-1 with a 1.46 ERA.

McIlroy buried the eagle putt , calmly bowed twice to the crowd and then punched the chilly Minnesota air with his fist .

U.S. captain Davis Love III at least could take consolation in a 5-3 lead , though the Americans wasted a chance to put Europe in a big hole .

" It's frustrating not to come out a little bit more ahead , " Love said .

Ryder Cup rookie Ryan Moore of Puyallup and playing partner J.B. Holmes had a shaky start and lost 3 and 2 to Spaniards Sergio Garcia and Rafa Cabrera Bello in fourballs .

Despite all the talk @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ a lead . That's where you want to be . You want to be on the right side of it . We keep ourselves on the right side of it all week , we'll be in good shape . "

Olivas , also known as the " panty bandit , " was detained after police caught him trying to pry open the back door of a store .

Property crime in the Topanga area is up 8 percent and nearly 20 percent since 2014 .

@ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ minutes when captain Soline Djoubi fired home from an indirect free-kick inside the box after keeper Marissa Zucchetto had been penalised for picking up a back-pass . Matters then went from bad to worse for Canada just before half-time when Claudia Dabda bustled her way through before crashing a low shot beyond the helpless Zuchetto .

That was the way the scoring stayed until 76 minutes , when Cameroon keeper Carole Mimboe conceded the clearest of penalties , racing out to bring substitute Lauren Raimondo crashing to the ground . Skipper Stratigakis then took responsibility for the kick and dispatched it superbly , directing a textbook kick into the top-right corner .
